standard_metadata.standard_description: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

hints.content: We can estimate to divide with friendly numbers.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  A *reasonable* estimate keeps the information from the largest place values.

images.alt: A number line with tick marks at 2400 and 2500. Halfway between 2400 and 2500 is an unlabeled tick mark. Between 2400 and the unlabeled tick mark, an orange arrow starting at an orange dot labeled 2419 moves left along the number line, pointing to the 2400 tick mark.

A number line with tick marks at 400 and 500. Halfway between 400 and 500 is an unlabeled tick mark. Between 400 and the unlabeled tick mark, a blue arrow starting at a blue dot labeled 435 moves left along the number line, pointing to the 400 tick mark.

A number line with tick marks at 6000 and 7000. Halfway between 6000 and 7000 is an unlabeled tick mark. Between 6000 and the unlabeled tick mark, a purple arrow starting at a purple dot labeled 6202 moves left along the number line, pointing to the 6000 tick mark.

hints.content: We estimate to add, subtract, multiply, and divide with friendly numbers.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  A reasonable estimate is close to the answer. The largest place values of each number change the quotient in big ways. So they help us get close enough.
